1479158635871842314.text: We saw federal law enforcement and National Guardsmen clear and secure the building. At the end of the day, there was law and law enforcement — and no one is above that law.

1479158634236071941.text: As dark as this violent assault on our democracy was, we also witnessed true heroism on that awful day. We saw Capitol Police officers risk everything to divert the mob and save lives.

1479158632147267594.text: What took place on this day was domestic terrorism — a violent attempt, rooted in a lie, to overturn the will of the majority of the American people, and one of the most egregious acts of domestic violent extremism we’ve ever seen on our shores.

1479158630557622280.text: The one moment that day when I choked up was when I realized how grateful I felt that my grandparents, including veterans of the Second World War, weren’t alive to see what was happening to our Capitol.

1479158628603080709.text: As the day unfolded, I thought of all the time I spent working overseas in countries where people are desperate for a shot at the kind of government we have here: democracy & self-determination. In 1973, Congress passed the War Powers Resolution (WPR) with bipartisan support. It says:
